questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding vitamin A?


	Obtained from animal sources like liver, egg yolks, and dairy products.
	Maintains healthy skin and mucous membranes.
	Deficiency leads to night blindness and an increased risk of childhood infections.
	It helps in calcium absorption
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1, 2, and 3

Explanation:

Sources of Vitamin A:

  • The richest source of Vitamin A is Halibut fish
  • Animal sources: Liver (beef, chicken, fish), Egg yolks, Dairy products (milk, cheese, butter), Fish liver oils.
  • Plant sources (provitamin A carotenoids): Orange/yellow fruits and vegetables (carrots, sweet potatoes, mangoes, papaya), Green leafy vegetables (spinach, kale, broccoli), Red palm oil

Functions of Vitamin A:

  • Vision: Essential for normal vision and low-light vision
  • Immune function: Supports immune cell development and mucosal barriers
  • Skin and epithelial cell health: Maintains integrity of skin and epithelial linings
  • Growth and development: Important for growth, especially in children and pregnancy
  • Antioxidant properties: Some carotenoid forms act as antioxidants
  • Involved in regulating gene expression
  • Deficiency can cause night blindness and increased risk of childhood infections

questions.text: Which stage of xerophthalmia is depicted in the following image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) X1B

Explanation:

The provided image illustrates Bitot spots belonging to the X1B classification of xerophthalmia.

Classification of Xerophthalmia:

Stage

Description

XN

Night blindness: Difficulty seeing in low light or at night.

X1A

Conjunctival xerosis: Dryness of the conjunctiva without foamy patches (Bitot spots).

X1B

Bitot spots: Presence of foamy, whitish accumulations on the conjunctiva.

X2

Corneal xerosis: The cornea's dryness makes it appear dull and hazy.

X3A

Corneal ulceration/keratomalacia (<1/3rd of the cornea)

X3B

Corneal ulceration/keratomalacia (>1/3rd of the cornea)

XS

Corneal scar: Scarring of the cornea resulting from the healing of ulcers or keratomalacia.

XF

Xerophthalmic fundus: Retinal changes associated with chronic Vitamin A deficiency.

 

  • The stages from X1A to X2 are reversible.

questions.text: What is the first clinical manifestation of Vitamin A deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Night blindness

Explanation:

  • Night blindness (XN) is the initial clinical manifestation of Vitamin A deficiency.
  • Individuals with night blindness have difficulty seeing in low light or at night.
  • This condition occurs because Vitamin A is essential for producing rhodopsin, a pigment found in the retina. (Rhodopsin = 11- cis Retinal + Opsin )
  • Without adequate Vitamin A, the eyes cannot adapt well to darkness, leading to night blindness.
  • Night blindness is an early indicator, alerting to possible deficiencies before more severe eye conditions develop.

questions.text: According to WHO criteria, which prevalence rate of night blindness indicates that xerophthalmia is a significant public health problem?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) More than 1.0%

Explanation:

The prevalence criteria for determining xerophthalmia is assessed in age groups 6 months to 6 years.

Stages

Description

Levels in community

(Prevalence)

XN

Night blindness

> 1%

X1B

Bitot spots

> 0.5%

X3A

Corneal ulceration/keratomalacia (<1/3rd of the cornea)

> 0.01%

XS

Corneal scar.

> 0.05%

questions.text: What is the recommended dosage for Vitamin A supplementation in a 2-year-old child diagnosed with Vitamin A deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 200,000 IU

Explanation:

  • Administer 2 lakh IU orally on 2 successive days.
  • All early stages of xerophthalmia can be reversed by administration of a massive dose of 200000 IU or 110 mg of retinol palmitate orally on two successive days.
  • IM dose = 1⁄2 of oral dose
  • All children with corneal ulcers should receive vitamin A whether or not deficiency is suspected.
 

<6 months

6 months-1 year

> 1 year

Day 1

50000 IU

1 lakh IU

2 Lac IU

Day 2

50000 IU

1 lakh IU

2 Lac IU

Day 14

50000 IU

1 lakh IU

2 Lac IU

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with weakness, fatigue, and tingling sensations in her extremities. Upon further investigation, she has dry beriberi. Which of the following dietary habits will most likely lead to this condition?

choices.text: Diet predominantly of polished white rice

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Diet predominantly of polished white rice

 

Explanation:

  • A diet predominantly of polished white rice can lead to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency as
    • Thiamine is lost during the process of milling.
    • It is water soluble; thus, further loss occurs during washing and cooking.
    • Thiamine is also lost if the food is baked with baking soda, e.g. bread and cereals.
    • Thiamine deficiency also occurs in chronic alcoholics (Wernike’s encephalopathy)
  • Deficiency of thiamine leads to
    • Dry beriberi (Peripheral neuritis)
    • Wet beriberi (High output cardiac failure)
    • Infantile beriberi (Seen in infants 2 - 4 months of age who are breastfed by thiamine deficient mother).
    • Wernicke's encephalopathy (Chronic alcoholics): Confusion + ophthalmoplegia + ataxia
  • To prevent thiamine deficiency due to dietary habits, it is advised to
    • Consume parboiled and under-milled rice.
    • Have a well-balanced diet.
    • Reduce alcohol consumption.

 

High fat, low-carbohydrate diet (Option A) is also known as the ketogenic diet. It does not cause thiamine deficiency, but it can lead to ketoacidosis in the body.

Vegan diet (Option C) consists of a good mix of plant-based products that are rich in thiamine; thus, vitamin B1 deficiency rarely occurs, but since the diet lacks dairy and animal products, it can lead to Vitamin B12, Vitamin D, and Iron and Calcium deficiency.

Gluten-Free Diet (Option D) is mainly used to manage celiac disease or gluten intolerance; it has no direct involvement in causing thiamine deficiency.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency leads to the condition in the image depicted below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vitamin B2

Explanation: The image shows angular stomatitis often associated with Vitamin B2 deficiency (Riboflavin).

Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin)

Sources

Function

Deficiency

  • Milk
  • Eggs
  • Liver
  • Green leafy vegetables
  • Cofactor for glutathione reductase.
  • Cofactor for metabolism of Vitamin B6, Niacin and Vitamin K
  • Antioxidant activity.
  • Maintenance of integrity of mucocutaneous membranes.
  • Angular stomatitis
  • Glossitis
  • Nasolabial dyssebacia

 

It can also lead to

  • Neuromotor dysfunction
  • Poor wound healing
  • Cataract

(Image-1: Geographic tongue, image 2- angular cheilitis, image 3- magenta colored tongue)

Riboflavin deficiency commonly occurs with pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency. Riboflavin is vital for producing flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), a key coenzyme in energy metabolism. Deficiency impairs energy production and nutrient metabolism.

 

Vitamin E (Option A) deficiency leads to ataxia, blindness, dementia and cardiac arrhythmias.

 

Vitamin B5 (Option B) is a precursor for Coenzyme A, and its deficiency leads to fatigue, headache, personality changes, muscle cramps, paresthesia, and muscle/abdominal cramps.

 

Vitamin B6 (Option D) deficiency leads to peripheral neuropathy and does not cause angular stomatitis, but it often occurs along with vitamin B2 deficiency, which can lead to angular stomatitis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female with dementia was brought to the emergency due to severe diarrhoea and skin lesions similar to the image given below. Investigations reveal niacin deficiency. Which of the following amino acids, if consumed in large quantities, can lead to the above condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Leucine

Explanation:

  • Leucine is a branched-chain amino acid that alters the tryptophan-niacin metabolic pathway when consumed in large quantities, worsening the symptoms of niacin deficiency.
    • It reduced hepatic uptake and intestinal absorption of tryptophan (precursor of niacin).
    • It inhibits several enzymes, such as hepatic tryptophan dioxygenase and kynureninase.
  • Food products that are pellagra genic are:
    • Jowar (Rich in leucine and poor in tryptophan).
    • Corn/maise (Poor in tryptophan)
  • Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, characterised by the "4 D's": dermatitis, dementia, diarrhoea, and can be fatal (Death).

questions.text:
Which of the following are NOT true regarding vitamin B9 and Vitamin B12?


	Both vitamin B9 and B12 deficiency lead to macrocytic anaemia.
	Both vitamin B9 and B12 supplementation prevent neural tube defects in pregnancy.
	Demyelinating neurological symptoms are associated with only Vitamin B12 deficiency.
	Castle's intrinsic factor is essential for folate absorption.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2 and 4

Explanation: Only vitamin B9 supplementation is recommended in the first trimester of pregnancy to prevent neural tube defects in the fetus. Castle’s intrinsic factor is essential for the absorption of cobalamin, not folate.

 

 

Folate - vitamin B9

Cobalamin - vitamin B12

Sources

Liver; Meat; Dairy products; Eggs; Fruits; Cereals; Green leafy vegetables

Liver; Meat; Milk; Eggs; Cheese; Synthesized by gut bacteria

(not found in food of vegetable origin)

Absorption

Absorbed from the proximal part of the small intestine.

Absorbed in terminal ileum, bound to intrinsic factor.

Uses

It helps in the synthesis of nucleic acids.

It helps in the synthesis of fatty acid(myelin) and DNA.

Deficiency

  • Macrocytic anemia (Statement 1)
  • Neural tube defects in neonates
  • No neurological symptoms (Statement 3)
  • Megaloblastic anemia (Statement 1)
  • Demyelinating lesion in the spinal cord
  • Infertility

Requirements

Men: 300 mcg/day.

Women: 220 mcg/day.

Pregnant: 570 mcg/day.

Children: 120-170 mcg/day.

Adults: 2-2 mcg/day.

Pregnancy: extra 0.25 mcg.

Lactation: extra 1 mcg.

Infants and children: 1.2 mcg.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with swollen and bleeding gums, easy bruising, and small red spots on his skin. His diet mostly consists of processed foods and lacks fresh fruits and vegetables. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vitamin C

Explanation: Scurvy occurs due to vitamin C deficiency and manifests as swelling and bleeding of the gums, easy bruising, delayed wound healing, and bleeding into joints.

  • Sources of vitamin C are Indian gooseberry, fresh fruits, green leafy vegetables, and germinating pulses.
  • Functions of vitamin C:
    • Hydroxylation of Collagen.
    • Iron absorption in the stomach.
    • Inhibition of nitrosamine formation in the intestine.
  • Manifestations of Vitamin C:
  • Bleeding gums
  • Subcutaneous bruising
  • Delayed wound healing
  • Weakness
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Anaemia (Vitamin C is essential for the absorption of iron from the diet)

Vitamin B2 (Option A) (riboflavin) acts as a cofactor for glutathione reductase, an antioxidant that protects the mucocutaneous membrane. Its deficiency leads to glossitis and stomatitis, not scurvy.

 

Vitamin D (Option C) is essential for calcium homeostasis and bone health; its deficiency leads to rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults.

 

Iron (Option D) is necessary for haemoglobin production, catechol metabolism, thermoregulation and muscle activity. Its deficiency leads to iron deficiency anaemia and impaired cell-mediated immunity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a past medical history of celiac disease visits the clinic complaining of fatigue, muscle weakness, and bone pain. Upon examination, she is found to have vitamin D deficiency. The doctor advises her to increase her intake of the vitamin D. All of the following are sources of this vitamin except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Whole grains

Explanation:

The patient's fatigue, muscle weakness, and bone pain are signs of vitamin D deficiency. Her history of celiac disease likely contributes to this deficiency due to impaired nutrient absorption.

While whole grains are nutritious and provide various vitamins and minerals, they are not a significant source of vitamin D.

 

Sources that are rich in vitamin D include:

  • The richest source is Halibut fish (Option B)
  • Sunlight exposure (Option A)
  • Liver, Egg yolk, butter, cheese, and cod fish. (Option C)

 

Function of vitamin D:

  • Intestine: Facilitates the absorption of calcium and phosphorus in the intestines.
  • Bone: Encourages proper bone mineralisation, stimulates bone resorption, and influences collagen maturation.
  • Kidney: Enhances phosphate reabsorption in the kidney tubules; has a variable effect on calcium reabsorption.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman visits a clinic complaining of fatigue, weakness, and pale skin. She has a medical history of menorrhagia, for which she sees a gynaecologist. The serum iron panel is ordered. Which of the following should the patient be advised to consume to prevent this mineral deficiency?


	Spinach
	Red meat
	Fortified cereals
	Dairy products
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 2, and 3.

Explanation:

Sources rich in iron:

Two types: heme-iron and non-heme iron.

  • Heme iron
    • Heme iron is better absorbed than non-heme iron.
    • Found in liver, meat, poultry, and fish.
    • Promotes absorption of non-heme iron in plant foods eaten concurrently.
  • Non-heme iron:
    • It is found in plant-based foods such as cereals, green leafy vegetables, legumes, nuts, oilseeds, jaggery, and dried fruits.
  • Additional Iron Sources: Cooking in iron vessels can significantly contribute to dietary iron in some areas.
  • Iron Content in Milk:
    • Low in all mammalian species.
    • Breast milk contains less than 0.2 mg/dL but has good bioavailability.

Bioavailability and Absorption Inhibitors:

  • Non-heme iron absorption is hindered by phytates, oxalates, carbonates, phosphates, and dietary fibre.
  • Foods like milk, eggs, and tea also inhibit iron absorption.
  • Indian vegetarian diets often contain high levels of these inhibitors (e.g., phytates in bran, phosphates in egg yolk, tannin in tea, and oxalates in vegetables).

questions.text: Which of the following is an important epidemiological indicator for monitoring iodine deficiency in the Goiter Control program?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Urinary iodine excretion

Explanation:

Urinary iodine excretion is an important epidemiological indicator for monitoring iodine deficiency in the Goitre Control program.

Surveillance Indicators:

  • Urinary iodine excretion
  • Goiter prevalence (Option A)
  • Prevalence of cretinism
  • Measurement of serum T4 and TSH levels
  • prevalence of neonatal hypothyroidism.

Goitre Control Programme:

  • The aim is to increase iodine intake.
  • Neonatal hypothyroidism is a sensitive marker of environmental iodine deficiency. (Option D)
  • Serum T4 levels are more sensitive indicators of thyroid insufficiency than T3 levels. (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following levels of fluorine in water leads to the development of dental carries?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 0.3mg/L

 

Explanation:

  • The given image depicts dental caries due to fluorine deficiency.
  • The recommended fluorine dose in water is 0.5 - 0.8 mg/L.
  • The Nalgonda technique is used to remove fluoride from water.

Fluorine content in water

Related symptoms

<0.5mg/L (Option A)

Dental caries 

 

1.5mg/L (Option B)

Mottling of teeth (dental fluorosis)

 

3-6mg/L (Option C)

Skeletal fluorosis

 

 

>10mg/L (Option D)

Crippling fluorosis

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, alopecia, and a distinctive rash shown in the image below. The child's mother reports that the symptoms have persisted despite various treatments. Which of the following nutrient deficiencies is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Zinc

Explanation:

Distinctive rash around the mouth and orifices of the face, along with diarrhea, and alopecia is called Acrodermatitis Enteropathica, an autosomal recessive condition caused by a defect in dietary zinc absorption in the duodenum and jejunum.

 

Role of Zinc:

  • Essential co-enzyme in metal enzymes like alkaline phosphatase.
  • Important structural component of gene regulatory proteins.
  • Involved in regulation, including gene expression.

Symptoms of zinc deficiency:

  • Diarrhea.
  • Mood changes.
  • Anorexia.
  • Neurological disturbances.
  • Hypogonadism
  • Growth retardation.
  • Alopecia (hair loss).
  • Weight loss.
  • Recurrent infections.

Copper (Option A) deficiency leads to neutropenia; it does not cause dermatitis in children.

Chromium (Option C) deficiency leads to insulin resistance and diabetes mellitus.

Molybdenum (Option D) deficiency leads to mouth and esophageal cancer.
